title: Trump imposes 25% tariff on imports of some AI chips
summary: STORY: :: FileU.S. President Donald Trump on Wednesday imposed a 25% tariff on certain AI chips under a new national security order.Affected products include Nvidia's H200 and a rival semiconductor from AMD.The proclamation says “the United States currently fully manufactures only approximately 10 percent of the chips it requires, making it heavily reliant on foreign supply chains."It says such reliance is a "significant economic and national security risk.”The move follows a nine-month investigation.It targets a number of high-end semiconductors meeting certain performance benchmarks and devices containing them.But it exempts chips bound for new data centers. Shares in Nvidia, AMD and Qualcomm edged lower in after-hours trading following the news. The Trump administration this week required that China-bound Nvidia H200 chips make a detour to the U.S. from Taiwan, where they are made, for testing by a third-party lab.:: NvidiaWhen the chips enter the U.S., they are subject to the new 25% levy.On Thursday, Taiwan signaled it was close to a deal with the U.S. on tariffs on its goods. Taiwan has been in talks with the U.S. to get the levies on its exports cut from 20% to 15%.Two Reuters sources said an announcement on a deal could come by the end of the month.

raw.headline: Trump imposes 25% tariff on imports of some AI chips
raw.summary: STORY: :: FileU.S. President Donald Trump on Wednesday imposed a 25% tariff on certain AI chips under a new national security order.Affected products include Nvidia's H200 and a rival semiconductor from AMD.The proclamation says “the United States currently fully manufactures only approximately 10 percent of the chips it requires, making it heavily reliant on foreign supply chains."It says such reliance is a "significant economic and national security risk.”The move follows a nine-month investigation.It targets a number of high-end semiconductors meeting certain performance benchmarks and devices containing them.But it exempts chips bound for new data centers. Shares in Nvidia, AMD and Qualcomm edged lower in after-hours trading following the news. The Trump administration this week required that China-bound Nvidia H200 chips make a detour to the U.S. from Taiwan, where they are made, for testing by a third-party lab.:: NvidiaWhen the chips enter the U.S., they are subject to the new 25% levy.On Thursday, Taiwan signaled it was close to a deal with the U.S. on tariffs on its goods. Taiwan has been in talks with the U.S. to get the levies on its exports cut from 20% to 15%.Two Reuters sources said an announcement on a deal could come by the end of the month.

title: TSMC’s Strong Outlook Shores Up Hopes of Sustained AI Boom
summary: It also foresees revenue growth of close to 30% in 2026, faster than the average analyst estimate.  Shares in key supplier ASML Holding NV rose 5% on Tradegate in Europe.  The outlook from TSMC — a bellwether for the artificial intelligence boom — reflects a development frenzy by the likes of Meta Platforms Inc. and Amazon.com Inc. that’s spurred demand for Nvidia Corp. accelerators.

title: Trump enacts 25% tariff on chips — with a caveat
summary: President Donald Trump enacted a new 25% tariff on “certain advanced computing chips” on Wednesday, according to a White House fact sheet. That includes Nvidia’s H200 chip and AMD’s MI325X. However, chips imported to support building up the US technological supply chain would be exempt.

title: 2026’s Biggest AI Trends: The Return of CPUs | INTC Stock, AMD Stock, NVDA Stock
summary: 24/7 Wall St. Analysts Eric Bleeker and Austin Smith are kicking the New Year off in style with 12 trends for AI investors to watch in 2026. Over the course of 12 videos, the two will share their thoughts on everything from the memory explosion to software stocks to robotics. In this video, Eric focuses on the unexpected return of CPUs in 2026. The rise of AI agents and Reinforcement Learning Environments is creating enormous demand for CPUs. That could lead to significant pricing power for leading CPU companies like Intel (Nasdaq: INTC) and AMD (Nasdaq: AMD).

title: The AI Boom Gets Its First Earnings Test of the Year. Watch TSMC Stock.
summary: When  Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing  reports fourth-quarter earnings on Thursday, investors will be watching for the company’s comments on revenue and capital expenditure for clarity on where the boom in artificial-intelligence processors goes from here.  TSMC is expected to report a net profit of 469.13 billion New Taiwan dollars ($14.86 billion), according to a FactSet poll of analysts’ estimates, up 25% from the same period a year ago.  The Taiwanese chip manufacturer releases monthly revenue figures, which makes it easier for investors to calculate fourth-quarter revenue.

title: Sales of a powerful Nvidia AI chip to China gets the greenlight, with conditions
summary: The Trump administration placed new security requirements on Nividia's semiconductor sales to China, but essentially greenlighted the export of its powerful H200 artificial intelligence chips to Chinese buyers.  Nvidia must ensure that there is an adequate supply in the U.S., and the H200 chips must undergo a third-party review before being exported to China, according to new rules set by the Commerce Department's Bureau of Industry and Security.  China won't be allowed to use the chips for military purposes and is not allowed to import more than 50% of the chips sold to U.S. customers.

raw.headline: Sales of a powerful Nvidia AI chip to China gets the greenlight, with conditions
raw.summary: The Trump administration placed new security requirements on Nividia's semiconductor sales to China, but essentially greenlighted the export of its powerful H200 artificial intelligence chips to Chinese buyers.  Nvidia must ensure that there is an adequate supply in the U.S., and the H200 chips must undergo a third-party review before being exported to China, according to new rules set by the Commerce Department's Bureau of Industry and Security.  China won't be allowed to use the chips for military purposes and is not allowed to import more than 50% of the chips sold to U.S. customers.
